doc_id: Anonymous - 1675 - The gentlewomans cabinet unlocked wherein is contained many excellent receipts for neat dressing of_page_8.xml
text:
The Gentlewomans
yolks of two Eggs for one Mess or
Draught, and so [drare] or less according
to the quantity of your Ile, beat them
very well, and take away the skin of the
yolks, and when the Ale boyls put them
in, and [tep] them stirring continually
and when it hath boil'd a while; sweeten it
with sugar; and if it be to eat, cut two
or three tosts of [it] to bread, tost them
dry, and put them to the Candle, but if it
be to drink put in none
To Stew Beef.
Take a good Rump of Beef cut from
the bones, shred Turneps and Carrets
small, with Spinnage and Lettice, put
all in a Pan and let it stew four hours
with so much Water, and a quart of
White-wine as will cover it, some
Pepper and Salt: when it is stewed
then put in a wine-glass full of good
Eldar Vinegar, and serve it with
Sippits.
To Boyl a Gammon of Bacon.
Water pour Gammon of Bacon
twenty-four hours, then put it into a
deep Kettle with sweet Hay, let it boyl
softly six or seven hours, and then take
it up with a Scummer and a Plate, and
take off the Skin whole, then stick your
Gam-
Cabinet Unlocked
Gammon full of Cloves, and strew on
some gross Pepper, then cut your skin
like sippets to garnish your Gammon:
and when you serve it, stick it with
Bay-leaves
To Boyl Brawn.
Water your Brawn twenty-four
hours, wash and scrape it four or five
times, then take it out of the water and
lay it on a clean table, and throw an
handful of salt on every Coilo., then
bind them up as fast as you can with
hemp or Bass, and put them in your
Kettle, when the Water boyleth, and
the scum ariseth, take it away : Let it
boyl so tender that you may thrust a straw
through it, then let it cool till the next
morning, and serve it.
To make a White-pot.
Take the best and sivierest Cream;
and boyl it with good stroze of Sugar and
Cinnamon, a little Rose-water : then
take it from the fire and put into it clean
pickt rice, but not so much as to make
it thick, and let it steep therein till it
be cold : then put in the Yolks of six
Eggs and two whites, Currants, Nutmeg
and Salt : then put it into the Pan
or Pot, as thin as if it were a Custard,
and
